title: 112_hr2958
content: The "Federal Employee Short-Term Disability Insurance Act of 2011" offers voluntary insurance to Federal employees for short-term injury, caring for family members, childbirth, or adoption/foster care arrangements. It amends Title 5 of the United States Code to include non-work related short-term disability insurance. The "Federal Employee Short-Term Disability Insurance Act of 2011" provides definitions for key terms such as Director, employee, and injury or disability. The Act also outlines the availability of insurance, contracting authority, benefits, premiums, preemption, studies, reports, audits, jurisdiction of courts, administrative functions, and cost accounting standards. The "Federal Employee Short-Term Disability Insurance Act of 2011" defines key terms like 'member of family' and 'carrier'. It establishes a program for insurance coverage for various situations, including caring for a family member or becoming a foster parent. The "Federal Employee Short-Term Disability Insurance Act of 2011" allows for insurance coverage for foster parenting or child adoption. Insurance is not available if the injury is due to willful misconduct, intention to cause harm, or intoxication. The Director can contract with carriers for disability insurance without competitive bidding. The Director ensures contracts for disability insurance are awarded based on qualifications, price, and competition. Each contract must detail benefits, premiums, enrollment period, and eligibility procedures. Premiums charged must adhere to specified conditions. Premiums under contracts must reflect benefit costs as determined by the Director. Contracts require carriers to provide payments to entitled employees and establish procedures for resolving disputes. Each contract under this section shall be for a term of not less than 3 years and not greater than 7 years, subject to review by the Director. The carrier's determination of employee eligibility for insurance coverage can be reviewed under the contract terms, with no authority for third-party reviewers to change contract terms. The rights and responsibilities of enrolled employees, insurers, and the Director continue until contract termination. The Director may prescribe minimum standards for benefit plans under this chapter. Contracts can be automatically renewed annually unless notice of non-renewal is given. Insurance coverage for enrolled employees only terminates upon separation from Federal service or non-payment of premiums. Benefits provided under this chapter offset other benefits received by the employee for the same injury or disability, including worker's compensation and disability retirement income. Contracts must not have preexisting condition exclusions, charge higher premiums, deny coverage, or drop coverage for employees with preexisting conditions. Incentives for employees receiving benefits to return to work must be provided. Employees who suffer an injury or disability, take leave to care for a family member, or make arrangements for adoption or foster care can receive benefits for up to 12 months. The benefits amount to 70% of the employee's annual pay at the time of the injury or disability. Employees can receive benefits for up to 12 months at 70% of their annual pay after completing a waiting period, with options to start on the 8th or 31st day of continuous injury or disability to care for a family member or make arrangements for adoption or foster care. Employees can receive benefits for up to 12 months at 70% of their annual pay after completing a waiting period, with options to start on the 8th or 31st day of continuous injury or disability to care for a family member or make arrangements for adoption or foster care. The waiting period can also be extended to the 91st or 181st day for additional leave to care for family members or make arrangements for adoption or foster care, with higher premiums for early benefit receipt. Sec. 8805 of the chapter states that eligible individuals must pay 100% of the premiums for insurance coverage, with the amount withheld from their pay. Carriers must keep records of all amounts received separately. The Employees' Life Insurance Fund covers expenses for administering the chapter and must be reimbursed within the first year of a contract. The Employees' Life Insurance Fund covers expenses for administering the chapter and must be reimbursed within the first year of a contract. A Non-Work Related Disability Insurance Administrative Account is established to defray expenses incurred by the Office of Personnel Management in administering the chapter. Carriers are required to make periodic contributions to the account to ensure its funding. The chapter establishes an Insurance Administrative Account to cover expenses incurred by the Office of Personnel Management. It also allows for underwriting standards for later enrollment and preempts any state laws related to non-work related disability insurance contracts. The chapter establishes an Insurance Administrative Account to cover expenses incurred by the Office of Personnel Management and allows for underwriting standards for later enrollment. No tax, fee, or monetary payment may be imposed on insurance premiums under this chapter, except for taxes on net income or profit applicable to a broad range of business activity. State laws related to subrogation or reimbursement for benefits provided under non-work related disability insurance contracts are also preempted. Sec. 8807 of this chapter requires contracts to include provisions for reports, audits, and studies. Federal agencies must provide necessary information to the Director. The Director conducts reviews to ensure plan competitiveness. Sec. 8808 grants jurisdiction to district courts for civil actions against the United States under this chapter. Claims against the United States under this chapter must exhaust administrative remedies before pursuing judicial review, unless precluded by other remedies. The Director is responsible for prescribing regulations and coordinating with other agencies to implement the program. Time spent receiving benefits under this chapter will be specified in regulations for pay increases and other employment rights. The carrier is required to provide periodic coordination. The carrier must provide periodic coordinated enrollment, promotion, and education efforts as directed by the Director. Cost accounting standards do not apply to insurance contracts under this chapter. Amendments are made to title 39, United States Code, and the analysis for part III of title 5, United States Code. The amendment made by subsection (a) applies to contracts taking effect in the first calendar year starting more than 18 months after enactment of this section.
